title: SCRUM'S THE WORD: Scotland's week goes from bad to worse as World Rugby are ready to take action
text:
Scotland's week got worse on Tuesday when World Rugby announced they are set to take disciplinary action against the country’s union.

The governing body are angry about SRU chief Mark Dodson’s remarks over the potential cancellation of their Japan match due to Typhoon Hagibis, which would have eliminated Scotland.

Tournament director Alan Gilpin said: ‘The rules are clear about appropriate behaviour. We have asked an independent disputes committee to look at the Scottish union’s comments.’

Scotland's week got worse on Tuesday with World Rugby set to take disciplinary action

The World Cup is smashing all domestic TV records with more than half of Japanese viewers watching the Brave Blossoms’ win over Scotland.

That’s over 60 million. The audience has more than doubled since the opening night against Russia.

The Scotland game was the most-watched TV programme of the year in Japan.

England scrum-half Willi Heinz is taking tips from the Japanese to get a grip of the slippery ball out here.

He spoke with Genki Okoshi, the No 9 for Japanese club Suntory Sungoliath, who has trained with England, and has decided to tape up his finger-tips.

‘I’ve noticed a few other players doing it as well,’ said Heinz.

A boost for Warren Gatland this week as son Bryn is flying out to see his dad’s Wales team.

The 24-year-old’s North Harbour side in New Zealand lost their domestic Ranfurly Shield match against Canterbury on Sunday, so Bryn is jetting up to Japan for the quarter-final against France.

The Springboks won’t be able to talk in Afrikaans to hide calls against Japan. The hosts have three South Africans — Wimpie van der Walt, Lappies Labuschagne and Pretoria-born Kotaro Matsushima.
